newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Austria cenbank welcomes EMU stability deal.
newsitem.headline: Austria cenbank welcomes EMU stability deal.

text.p: Austrian central bank director Adolf Wala on Friday welcomed a deal hammered out by European Union finance ministers in Dublin to enforce fiscal discipline in Europe's planned single currency.

"The stability pact is an important building block for the currency union," he told Reuters in an interview. "We're very happy about it. The stability pact ensures the sustained stability of the euro."

Wala said the definition of the precise conditions under which countries should be exempt from fines for running excessive fiscal deficits after European economic and monetary union (EMU) was less strict than Germany had hoped for.
"It's a compromise formula," he said. "We are happy that it has come to such a compromise. The important thing is that (the Germans) wanted agreement on a stability pact, and that's what they got."

According to the accord, a country will be exempt from fines if gross domestic product (GDP) has fallen by an annual 2.0 percent or more. If GDP falls by between 0.75 and 2.0 percent, ministers will decide on possible fines. -- Knut Engelmann, Vienna newsroom +431 53112 274
